ygData.subject: Re: Python NEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ashot, Looks like really nice work.  What is your affiliation with UT?  Are you a grad student?  I m surprised I hadn t heard about what you re uy to

Hi Ashot,

Looks like really nice work.  What is your affiliation with UT?  Are 
you a grad student?  I'm surprised I hadn't heard about what you're 
uy to before.

A few comments..

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ashot_Petrosian" <ashot@m...> wrote:
> 	I have implemented a Python version of NEAT myself which is 
> feature-complete and has been successfully tested on XOR and 
double 
> pole balancing, and which I'm using now to evolve controllers for 
some 
> simple soccer playing bots.  I should say that my version is not a 
> carbon copy of the original in implementation and is in fact 
different 
> in a few areas by quite a bit (although I think functionally 
mostly 
> equivalent).  The three biggest differences that I can think of 
are 
> that speciation is done continuously without distinct species 
> (individuals get fitness modifications depending on how new and 
how 
> rare their innovations are, and probablistically mated based on 
> similarity), there is no genotype - crossover and mutation is just 
> done directly, and links don't have their own innovation ids 
(instead 
> its a tuple of the innovation ids that they connect).   I can 
describe 
> these in more detail, but I don't think they are very interesting. 
> Suffice it to say that I can't guarantee that this will work 
> identically to original NEAT on every problem, although it has 
done 
> well thus far.
> 

The continuous speciation idea is interesting.  People have 
speculated on doing something like that for a long time actually, 
but I don't know of anyone who actually did it before.  It would be 
an interesting study in its own right to see if doing that improves 
the algorithm.  One thing it makes me wonder about is that when you 
have discrete species you can set a target # of species and 
use "dynamic thresholding" to hold that number stable.  Since you 
don't have an actual # in your implementation, you can't set a 
target in the same way.  This brings up what the benefit of setting 
targets is.  One benefit is that it allows you to make sure you 
don't get explosions in the # of species, which would lead to a lack 
of diversity within each species.  In other words, the whole 
population could end up separated from each other.  Another nice 
thing is it allows several themes to totally diverge from each other 
over long periods of time.  In your scheme, it seems possible that 
because there is no particular guard in place keeping any two 
individuals from mating, over time you might get more uniformity and 
convergence.  Not sure about this though, of course it depends on 
your parameters...but I wonder how things compare.


> 	Also, I have implemented a module to save and retrieve 
networks and 
> evolutionary runs to and from a mySQL database, a module to 
visualize 
> arbitrary parameters from the database, a 3d network visualizer, 
and a 
> soccer domain with a monitor.  I ported the network evaluation 
code to 
> Pyrex (C) to speed up the simulations some as well.  If Tom or 
anyone 
> else is interested in any this the code it is relatively simple 
(the 
> part that implements NEAT is ~500 lines), it will be here soon 
(once 
> I'm finished cleaning it): 
> 
> 	http://www.freshraisins.com/neat
> 
> 	(at the moment you can see a screenshot and some videos of 
evolved 
> behaviour)
> 

Let me know when you are done with this and I will link it off my 
sites.  I really like the 3D visualization of the network.  I 
thought about doing something like that a long time ago but never 
got around to it.  It's pretty fun to see the network being 
manipulated.

I'm curious though, what is the meaning of the "species" sizes if 
there are no discrete species in the system?  Do you do a post-hoc 
speciation just for graphing purposes?

 
> 	Joe (or anyone really) - I haven't had a chance to look at 
your code 
> yet, but I am curious to know how you kept the GA and the network 
> seperate and still had innovation numbers?  I found that this was 
the 
> most difficult thing to deal with and essentially made any sort of 
> strict meaningful OO seperation difficult to impossible. 
>  

I'm actually not sure why this is difficult...I will leave it to OO 
experts to consider...

> 	Also, when I was first looking over Ken's code as a 
reference I 
> massaged his comments into Natural Docs format, in case someone 
finds 
> this useful it is here:
> 
> 	http://www.freshraisins.com/neatdoc
>  

Wow...it's cool to see it so well laid out.  Let me know if I can 
link this from the NEAT pages and I will do so...it would be helpful 
to people I have a feeling.

ken
